data.value: This function uses Pearson's definition of correlation (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pearson_correlation_coefficient).
is not specified, the output will be self correlation (e.g. all 1's), except for
for correlations of equal valued sequences; this is the result of a 0/0 division error.
, the output will be a MultiIndex DataFrame with the original index on the first level, and the
DataFrame columns on the second level.
In the case of missing elements, only complete pairwise observations will be used.
If not supplied then will default to self and produce pairwise output.

If False then only matching columns between self and other will be used and the output will be a DataFrame. If True then all pairwise combinations will be calculated and the output will be a MultiIndexed DataFrame in the case of DataFrame inputs. In the case of missing elements, only complete pairwise observations will be used.
Delta Degrees of Freedom.  The divisor used in calculations is
For NumPy compatibility and will not have an effect on the result.
Return type is the same as the original object with
The below example shows a rolling calculation with a window size of four matching the equivalent function call using

link.data: # numpy returns a 2X2 array, the correlation coefficient

data.value: The below example shows a similar rolling calculation on a DataFrame using the pairwise option.

data.out:
X         Y
0 X       NaN       NaN
  Y       NaN       NaN
1 X       NaN       NaN
  Y       NaN       NaN
2 X       NaN       NaN
  Y       NaN       NaN
3 X  1.000000  0.626300
  Y  0.626300  1.000000
4 X  1.000000  0.555368
  Y  0.555368  1.000000

signature.value: corr(self, other: 'DataFrame | Series | None' = None, pairwise: 'bool | None' = None, ddof: 'int' = 1, **kwargs)
